did.abstract: Robert L. Potts was a community organizer, educator, and Episcopal priest. The Robert L. Potts Papers documents his many professional obligations, including his community endeavors in Detroit, his service within the Ann Arbor Public Schools, and his involvement with the Episcopal Diocese of Michigan.

bioghist.p: Robert Lester Potts was a community organizer, educator, and Episcopal priest. He was active in both Detroit and Ann Arbor. Born on January 28, 1923 in Muskogee, Oklahoma to Beatrice Onque and Howard William Potts, he completed high school in Kansas City, Kansas before earning his A.B. at Lane College (Jackson, Tennessee) in 1945. He spent the next two years as an officer in the United States Air Force, with duties in Biloxi, Mississippi and Hampton, Virginia. He was ordained as a minister of the Methodist Church, serving in Tennessee, Illinois, and Michigan from 1948 until 1963. In this time, he earned a Master of Divinity from Garrett Theological Seminary in 1952 and an honorary doctorate from Lane, where he had previously served as college chaplain and instructor of religion and social sciences.

After briefly serving as President of Texas College, in 1964 Potts was ordained as an Episcopal priest by the Diocese of Michigan. Potts served the city of Detroit over the next four years, including tenures as Executive Director of the Citizens' Committee for Equal Opportunity and coordinator for the Mayor's Youth Opportunity Program.

In Ann Arbor, he directed the Model Cities Program before his 1970 appointment as Ombudsman for the Ann Arbor Public Schools. His chief responsibility in this capacity was to mediate public grievances to the school district. He maintained these duties after he was promoted to Assistant Superintendent for Human Relations & Community Services, a position that he held until his retirement in 1986. In this time span Potts also earned an Ed.D. from the University of Michigan in 1975.

Potts served fifteen years as a member of the clerical staff of St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Ann Arbor. In addition, the Diocese of Michigan installed Potts as an Archdeacon in 1988. He spent the next fifteen years of his life serving on the boards of countless philanthropic organizations, most notably the Shelter Association of Ann Arbor and Avalon Housing, Inc. Potts died on December 23, 2004 at the age of 81.

scopecontent.p: The Robert L. Potts Papers documents his many professional obligations. It includes his community endeavors in Detroit, his service within the Ann Arbor Public Schools, and his involvement with the Episcopal Diocese of Michigan. Speeches, reports and executive board meeting minutes constitute much of the archive.

The collection is arranged into four series: Personal/Family, Civic Organizations, Ombudsman, and Episcopal Priest. It is important to note that photographs and correspondence are nested within the various series.

scopecontent.p: The Personal/Family series contains biographical materials and items pertaining to the Potts family. These include obituaries, newspaper clippings, family photographs, and correspondence. Also of note is an oversize scrapbook that features Potts's handling of the racial strife experienced in the Ann Arbor Public Schools during the 1970's.

scopecontent.p: The Civic Organizations series is subdivided between Potts' activities in Detroit and in Ann Arbor. The former reflects records of the Metropolitan Detroit Citizens Development Authority, of which Potts was an Executive Committee member, and the Mayor's Youth Opportunity Council, which Potts chaired as a direct response to the Detroit riots of 1967. A considerable proportion of the files pertaining to the Youth Opportunity Council contain photographs of Detroit youth engaged in an array of educational and social activities. The second subdivision holds materials that focus primarily on his concern for affordable housing in Ann Arbor, as demonstrated by his being a founding board member of Avalon Housing, Inc.

scopecontent.p: Three large sections compose the Ombudsman series: Assistant Superintendent of Ann Arbor Public Schools, publications, and the University of Michigan. The first section has official reports from Potts's office. The agency was responsible for addressing citizens' grievances to the school district. Recurring issues are race, class, and gender. This section also has a wealth of text speeches that Potts delivered during his tenure. The second section contains two of Potts's publications on the topic of Ombudsmanship. The third section is an assortment of items from his time as a University of Michigan graduate student, including a bound copy of his dissertation.

scopecontent.p: The Episcopal Priest series is organized into three groups. The first consists of Potts's sermons delivered from 1977-1994, non-inclusive, and contains both text and audio files. The second grouping represents religious ceremonies from 1979-1996 that Potts officiated, the majority of which were eulogies and marriages. Included are the texts of speeches in addition to a sampling of the note cards he used. The final grouping in the series is a list of topical files. Particular highlights include the United Ministries in Higher Education (Eastern Michigan University chapter), Potts's installation as Archdeacon, records of the McGehee Fund, and a personal diary kept during the later years of his life. This grouping offers a unique insight into the role of the church as an agent of social and economic justice in Southeastern Michigan.
